chapters.chapterTitle: A Call to Rebuild the Temple

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Haggai 1:1-16 aloud, focusing on the contrast between the ruined temple and the paneled houses of the returned exiles.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'this house lies in ruins' (v.2) which emphasizes the neglect of God's house
Pay attention to the emotional shift from criticism to hope in verses 12-14: 'the LORD stirred up the spirit of Zerubbabel and Joshua...'
The phrase 'consider your ways' (v.5) appears as a call to self-reflection and is repeated in the context of the temple's neglect

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the returned exiles), WHAT (the call to rebuild the temple), WHERE (the land of Judah), and WHY (the temple's ruin reflects spiritual neglect).
tips: Zerubbabel and Joshua are the key leaders the prophet addresses
The temple is in ruins while the exiles build their own homes (paneled houses)
The LORD's command is tied to the exiles' spiritual condition and their failure to prioritize God's house

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the critique of the exiles' priorities (v.2-5), the LORD's call to action (v.6-7), or the spiritual stirring (v.12-14)?
tips: The phrase 'you have sown much, and harvested little' (v.5) powerfully illustrates the spiritual barrenness
The contrast between the exiles' busyness with their own houses and the temple's ruin (v.2) highlights a critical moral failure
The LORD's stirring of the spirit (v.12) shows God's active involvement in bringing about the rebuilding

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Haggai trying to communicate to the returned exiles about the priority of God's temple and their spiritual condition?
tips: Haggai emphasizes that the temple's rebuilding is a sign of the exiles' spiritual renewal and obedience
The temple represents God's presence and the community's relationship with Him; neglecting it shows a broken covenant
This call to rebuild foreshadows the New Covenant in Christ, where the true temple is the body of Christ

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'paneled houses', the spiritual condition of the exiles, or the role of the temple in the community?
tips: 'Paneled houses' refers to well-built, comfortable homes that the exiles were constructing, contrasting with the temple's ruin
The phrase 'blowed it away' (v.5) is a metaphor for God's rejection of their efforts due to spiritual neglect
The temple in Haggai's time was the central place of worship and the symbol of God's covenant with Israel

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you 'consider your ways' (v.5) and prioritize God's kingdom over your own needs this week?
tips: Identify one area where you are building your life around temporary things (like a house) rather than God's kingdom
Spend time reflecting on whether you are 'sowing much but harvesting little' in your spiritual life
Take one step to 'go up to the hills and bring wood' (v.6) by seeking God's will in a small but meaningful way

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the returned exiles to consider their ways and for God to stir your spirit to rebuild His kingdom.
tips: Thank God that He is the one who stirs the spirit of those who will rebuild His temple
Ask for the courage to prioritize God's house over your own needs
Pray for the church to be a community that actively rebuilds God's kingdom, just as Haggai called for
